review_title: Avanade Singapore is not at all worth to signup
pros:
They have impressive presence around the world.
They have inherited benefit from Microsoft and Accenture which turn bad sometime.. read Cons.
They have some really good talent at work in case of Europe and US, India.
cons:
In Short i will explain my story : They get hired me from all the way from India for a crucial job as they are in trouble with Sitecore Project. They offered me a permanent role upfront as nobody will come and join on contract basis on more experience level.
Whole experience in project is like hell as Project is run by the Accenture, Avanade provide only resourcing and have no control over project. Accenture know little about the technology but they know sure about money and time.

They keep extending my probation until one day when they suddenly decide to drop me on basis of my consultancy skils (Bu**s**t) as they can't question the work i have done and skills i have technically. So the original game plan is to hire a senior resource a short term and once project is finish and if they don't have any other Sitecore project parallel then kick him out.

The moral of story is they too short minded and not have any vision like building competency or have patience. They only work on principal of resourcing and billability of day to day basis. 
They can fire you anytime. There whole business revolves around the accenture business means they don't have substantive business of there own so Accenture guys are real boss.

Don't join them until you have solid vision for you defined by them.

pros: Great Work Culture, Work and Life balance, New Learning Opportunities, Great Compensation
cons: None as I Never felt bad about this company

review_title: Open culture and visibility to Top Management
pros:
- Getting to work on latest microsoft technologies
- Employee benefits are good (healthcare, personal devices, continuous learning)
- Senior management is approachable ( Of course, you have to contribute to make yourself visible)
- Established brand

1. Avanade in the consulting business, so customer comes first. This is something that we have to understand/embed into your brains.

2. All organisations will have internal politics, if there is no politics - how is that even considered a working place? After all, it's humans working in organisations; not robots. You pick which battles are worth fighting for.Learning to let go and not getting succumbed is key in any organization is an important trait in any company.

3. Work environment is good and an open culture than most other companies in Singapore.

4. If you are able to make yourself visible and do quality work in your job, the "recognition" is very good.

5. Truly cross cultural and get to work with a lot of counterparts from across the globe.
cons:
- Salary package and bonus component
- Work may sometimes be exhausting based on the project

pros:
- Good remuneration package
- Open culture
cons:
Management likes to claim that the Avanade culture is not the same as the Accenture, but this is not the case.

- Consistent long hours are a must even when your workload is on track - else you are considered as unmotivated. So be prepared to work long hours almost everyday.
- Tolerates openly biased managers.
- High pressure: superiors will scrutinise your every move.
- High employee turnover.

review_title: Best place to get close to Microsoft Technologies (other than Microsoft itself)
pros: Cutting edge technologies, 80 hours mandated training annually, lots of training materials, good network of experts.
cons: Risk averse. Good people often sent to the front lines to rescue "fires", while not-so-good ones enjoy time on the bench doing trainings and easy works. At the end of the day, the "exceed exceptional" receives only 2% more salary increase than those that "meet expectation" due to the salary guide and banding. It is important to get a lead who knows your performance well.

pros:
1) The vision of the company is great - To be the leading innovator on the Microsoft platform and that's what they are trying to do. 
2) Surrounded by like minded and passionate technical folks
cons:
1) Ultimately, its all about chasing billable work. Push comes to shove, vision and good intentions goes out the window. This happens VERY often.
2) Management seems to believe that the company compensation is competitive when each and every ex-Avanade gets attractive offers.
3) Lack of a proper technical career progression path - everyone is expected to be a solution architect + project manager + pre-sales support, ALL at the same time.

review_title: good colleagues but not so good managers
pros: Global MNC and is a microsoft partner. colleagues are helpful and you get a good mix of people to work with. Some manager value work-life balance and respect your time.
cons: Lately a lot of politics with the appointment of new leads, who are only supporting and pulling their own group of people up and ignoring the rest which causes the other employees to stagnate in their positions for very long.

review_title: Great company, pity it's so closely linked of accenture
pros: Avaande have Reasonable remuneration and are an innovative company overall, plus are highly respected in some markets (however not Singapore).
cons: Working on Accenture projects is a big driver of attrition because Accenture view success primarily along financial lines and not what is achieved for the customer. This leads to death march type projects where consultants are worked into the ground until they are replaced by contractors.

pros:
Good benefit package.
Certain leaders in the upper management are really good role models.
cons: Most projects are not self-sourced by company itself, so a lot of times employees have to conform to the "parent" company's work ethics. (If you come in late to work / go home early, you'll be penalized and sometimes, escalated to Avanade's upper management) Even if you complain about it to management, Avanade will not be able to do much for you other than telling you to take a sabbatical (non-paid) or just tolerate it till the project ends. They won't be able to take you off the project completely and immediately.

pros: Avanade/Accenture work in collaboration in Singapore in multiple projects. Employees are granted access to a senior staff as a mentor and they work in co-ordination mapping future career map of the employee.Management defends employees and supports them in case of any issues with clients.

pros: Certification programs Can work as an individual contributor Trains a person to become a true independent consultant
cons: Be sure to align with Microsoft based projects vs Accenture projects when you can. Avanade is, for the most part, the tech bench for Accenture and Accenture projects that need resources are weak project teams with terrible leaders. The others move from project to project in packs. Accenture will also lie to achieve a goal and Avanade HR will not help you. In terms of HR, Avanade HR should acquaint themselves with the "Human" concept of human resources as they seem to truly dislike people. There are some very dishonest people up and down the chain here and you must be able to navigate it successfully. I'm leaving in the next 3 weeks because of it. It's hard to invest in your career here with such poor leadership and terrible HR. For younger folks, it's a good place to start and stay < 2yrs until you can find something better. Taka dvantage of the certifications and training when you can even though the majority of projects you'll be on will be AWS vs Azure.

The whole “culture” of “do what matters” is a complete charade. If you work here, make sure to keep your guard up.

review_title: Too big - you won’t matter as a person
pros: High profile projects and great delivery teams. Decent work hours and decent vacation.
cons:
So much overhead! WAY TOO MANY “leaders” who haven’t actively worked on a project since 1999 who “tell” you how to run projects. I have weekly leadership call to review my project - with over 10 people?  Instead of asking questions it’s an opportunity for them to lecture and degrade the delivery teams. 

Absolutely ridiculous oversight on projects. They hire overqualified people and put them in demeaning positions with tons of leadership overriding every single decision. 

Azure DevOps use is highly over complicated with many, many people meddling in your project, changing work item types, states, etc without telling anyone. If it takes an extra team to manage the tool (ADO) you’ve failed. 

I’m forced to carry offshore folks who aren’t qualified and take more time to manage than it’s worth. 

Leadership? First - TOO MANY! Wipe out most of ‘middle management’ Quite frankly our leaders care more about the company profile and touting the environment than paying attention to the workers and the work. 

Finally, benefits are via Accenture. They’ve  screwed up my paycheck - there’s NO WAY you’re getting in touch with a “person.” After several months of trying to recover lost pay due to a clerical error I was told it could take months to straighten out. Meantime - I had to take a 401k loan to pay my bills. Really? 

They do not care about your qualifications - they care about bodies on projects.

cons: Bureaucratic application of multitude of controls. Some are totally meaningless. Sales and Delivery alignment is in word only. Project support is thin and when things go a bit south, even less support is shown as people don't want to be associated with bad project. People appear to get fast and sometimes undeserved promotions based on gender. Merger of newer acquisitions did not go well neither for acquired company employees nor for Avanade employees with some acquired company employees getting unrealistically higher role gradings than they are capable of working at.

review_title: Avoid this Company for Software Development roles unless you have 5-7+ yrs exp. - A warning during economic downturn
pros: I have been working for this company for several months as a full stack developer and was initially hired under the assumption that I would be immediately placed on a project. However, upon arrival, I discovered that they had no work for me. Instead of laying me off, they have recently assigned me to a project that does not align with the job description for which I was hired. I have been stuck on the bench for several months, watching my career gap grow on my resume and now find myself faced with a difficult choice: either stay with Avanade and watch my career suffer, or quit and struggle financially. A layoff with a severance package (or even just firing me, giving me access to unemployment) would have been the more humane option, but instead, the company has kept me on the bench for months and now presents me with an ultimatum. They fail to take responsibility for over hiring and the impact of the economic downturn on their staffing needs. It is unclear to me how Avanade is still in operation. Other positive reviews may be from long-term employees who were already placed on projects before the economic crash, so they have a vastly different experience. Keep this in mind when considering working here. The only positive aspect is that the company paid me for several months while I was on the bench, allowing me to search for internal and external job opportunities, but the emotional toll and stress of this situation has not been worth it.
cons: This is a warning for anyone considering working for this company. The company is currently experiencing a large number of employees on the "bench," meaning that they do not have any real work available and many employees are spending their time interviewing internally and networking for potential projects. Developers are being placed on projects that do not align with their job description and are more suited for business analysts. If you value your career as a developer, you should be aware that working here could lead to a significant gap in your resume and you will not gain valuable skills. While the company may try to downplay the situation, it is likely to negatively impact your career. There are a few technical projects available, but the internal interview process to be placed on one is competitive, and it is unlikely that you will be successful unless you have 5+ years of experience. Keep in mind the date of my post, when the economy improves in the tech sector this situation may change, but for now, even if you are desperate for a job, it is best to continue searching for other opportunities.

job_title: Candidate Engagement Lead in New City, NY
pros: I joined Avanade four months ago and it is an amazing firm with amazing people. From a technology perspective, as Microsoft's #1 Partner globally, Avanade is at the cutting edge. Equally the business operates in a truly ethical manner as it strives to make a genuine human impact. The training and opportunities here are second to none. From a personal perspective two things really stand out: the support we receive from a professional and personal perspective; and the people here. Avanade leads the way from an Inclusion and Diversity perspective: many firms 'talk the talk' but Avanade 'walks the walk' - lead by our inspirational CEO Pam Maynard. The inclusive environment at Avanade encourages everyone to be their true authentic selves; we are a community with various Employee Network Groups; last year 41% of the people we hired were women; 60% of our Board are women; and we have a genuinely diverse and intersectional workforce. The welcome and support I've had since joining has been incredible; and it is a privilege to work with such a talented yet humble community of incredible, inspirational and diverse people. We're encouraged to be brave, reassured to think outside the box, think of new ideas and ways of working - and try them out. In addition, the remuneration package is best in class (great pay, benefits, PTO, comprehensive health care etc etc) - and the offices are AMAZING. We have a flexible working policy so not only do you choose where you work; only going into an office as and when you want to (I go in quite a lot as the NYC office is superb and I like meeting up with colleagues as and when they choose to come in). We also have an 'alternative work week' which allows us to condense our hours into a four day week if we choose.
cons: Honestly, I can't think of any Cons whatsoever!

At the end of the day it’s Accenture. You work 90% of your time under Accenture. You are sent on projects with no training and a lot of times without knowledge on the product you are going to work with. You only get internal trainings (that are like jokes, for instance 1hr a week for 4 weeks to learn IaC…), little time for self study and get only Microsoft exams vouchers.
No work/life balance, as per Accenture tradition, despite all the good projects about this they advertise (forget to have 4 days long working week working 10 hours a day. You only will work 10 hours a day, if you are lucky.).
And last but not least the Accenture culture: always spend at least half of your time looking at your back. Expect always a knife in your back as soon as something goes wrong. No one is interested on the “why” a problem pc ours, but only on the “who” is getting screwed for that.
Plus, if you work less then 10 hours and you don’t answer phone also out of your business hours (weekend included) you’re not good for them.
They only try to avoid these things by words, but when it comes to the facts, nothing is done

review_title: compagnie de merde, excellent recruiting tactics
pros:
- Easy interview process
- 1 month trip to Chicago for "training"
- "Fun"(but conceited) colleagues
cons:
- Dumbest training you'll ever go through. Makes you wonder about the quality of people they hire; CS new grads who don't know HTML/CSS is typical.
- Bad job placements. A hit or miss. You can be on the bench for months, then end up at a call center for another four months. Of course, some people (bad developers too) may luck out, and end up in a very good placement, and get a gold ticket to equally good placements moving forward.
- Too much emphasis on certificates. The Microsoft certificates (value = ~$200 USD) are great if you love having no life after work and memorizing and regurgitating Azure facts. And what more, you can end up with countless virtual certificates later (they tell you tech companies love certificates [this "fact" is not backed])
- Promotions based on certifications. You might be a bad dev, but you'll get promoted sooner with more certificates, than another dev who actually knows how to code.
- Some of the dumbest developers you'll work with in the industry. They may be 2 - 3 levels above you (god forbid, they might even be managers), and they'll be asking you for help every day. But at the end of the day, they'll earn double your salary and have the final voice on your promotions. 
- Non-transparent promotion standards.
- Sketchy top tier leadership. Leadership will gossip about YOU. God forbid, you'd better hope you aren't one of the people that they accidentally gossip then "send all" to the whole department.

review_title: Do NOT join here as a graduate - particularly in Canberra
pros:
Free Microsoft training and certification
Very generous parental leave for both mothers and fathers
Annual bonuses are flexible
A subsidiary of Accenture - so there is a share purchase plan for ACN traded on NYSE
Decent work events for team building (boozy nights/lunches/etc)
cons:
Near zero career progression and development, particularly for those early in their IT careers. I'd pivoted from a more academic setting, and actually forgot more than I learned at this place, due to stagnation.

Some senior managers look after their own metrics for their bonus, often at the expense of their direct reports - as a purported IT SME, I was working on proofreading documents - which in turn resulted in a regression into substance abuse because of this feeling of worthlessness.

No flexibility once you are on a large client - you're a bum on a seat to earn money for T&E contracts rather than a person, so no real chance to change roles or expand experience.

Wages are inflexible and pegged to an annual % increase, rather than looking at market movements for similar roles - if you decide to sign on here: make sure you get paid properly from the start, and really push year on year to make sure your wage stays competitive.

If you end up working for a federal govt client - you will stagnate, and your skills will not develop. You will not have a good time. If you join Avanade in Australia, do NOT go to Canberra. That office (#) will take advantage of your naiivety and good will.

cons:
This place changed for the worse over the last few years. They have an excellent new US president. 
But they have ZERO loyalty to tenured employees. So watch your back.

You MUST be client relevant and billable if you’re in the consulting workforce or your days are numbered. If you volunteer or are asked to perform an internal role, get out of it as soon as you can because they don’t care to see you develop or grow in the role and you’ll have a huge target on your back. I was there for a long time, since the beginning of the company. Trust me, they don’t care unless you’re billing a customer, regardless of your tenure. It’s incredibly disappointing and not at all what I’d expect from the company.
The senior leadership is also being taken over by ex-IBMers who have a reputation as being difficult to work with and work for.
Took a long time to get senior female leaders.

job_title: Senior Cyber Security Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Huge company with a great rep and amazing benefits.
cons: Left because of the vax mandate.

pros:
* 80+ hours of training allowed each year. Even on extended projects, you'll be able to take training days here and there. Between projects you will likely have time to train and get certifications at regular pay
* Extended benefits starting at 500 dollars, but 1500+ after promotion to senior position. Can be used to buy any tech product, office supplies/equipment, health services/gear, bills, etc.
* Clear path towards promotion
* Assigned a Career Advisor who helps you accomplish your goals
* Flexibility - unlike other IT consulting companies, you can say no to projects with minimal explanation. You can ask for a different Career Advisor if it's not working out, you can ask to only be assigned to remote work in your field of expertise. At worst, they will look for roles that fit your needs first until you've been on the "bench" for an extended period
* Local & remote events/Networking opportunities
* More relaxed than other IT Consulting companies
* Helpful and relatable coworkers
* Weekly/Bi-weekly/Monthly meetings to keep you up to date on the latest technology within your talent community
* Floating Holidays, Holidays, 4 weeks + vacation pay accrued and capped at 200? hours until you use it
* Great pay. Your pay is reviewed periodically and you will get an increase to match industry standard. Your pay will also be increased dramatically if you get promoted. Bonuses ++
* Paid travel
* The culture is amazing and inclusive. Social issues are discussed, and like many tech companies, it is pretty left-leaning. So if it bothers you to see an optional meeting or two on your calendar to give light to certain social issues, an email received about an LGBTQ+ group forming, or having coworkers openly discuss their viewpoints that you may or may not agree with, this might not be the environment for you (or you could just ignore it?). Personally, I love it and find it quite interesting.
cons: * Sometimes you'll get put on an Accenture led project (our partner company), and it can be a totally different experience. Expected to work over 8 hours, but only report 8 hours. Avanade leadership says to contact someone about this, but it's kind of a known thing that happens on Accenture projects across the board. Also, Accenture workers aren't as fun to work with :)

pros:
Avanade is the leader in Microsoft technologies, and encourages their people to push the envelope of the possible.
The underlying reason is they put their people first.
During COVID, the immediate thinking from the CEO was to reassure and support their staff, with clear promises and direction followed by action.
Significant investment in people, technology and processes coupled with strong leadership teams has enabled the company to not only weather headwinds, but thrive when others suffered from heavy attrition and brain drain.
Significant bonuses as well as special bonuses have been paid out across the board.
cons: As with all large enterprises in the SI space, there is a complex matrix organization to navigate, however, unlike other organizations I have been a part of, there is constant vigilance of breaking down silo's and collaborating globally.

review_title: A great company to advance your career
pros:
Very different culture to traditional companies, no visible hierarchy, directors are engaged with all staff offering guidence and transparent and honest updates on company performance and goals.

Huge focus on staff upskilling,training and certifications - all free.

No ego's - everyone, at all levels, offers help and advice, a big emphasis on knowledge sharing and best practices.

Big opportunities to advance your career on a merit basis, with clear guidelines on what you need to do. No boys club or favoritism.

Different career paths available based on your skillset and ambitions, i.e solution architect path, advisory, transformation consultant..., even directors stay technical focused and engaged on bigger projects

Multi-cultural, a great opportunity to work with people from all different backgrounds from all over the world.
cons: Ireland employees don't have the same level of benefits as the UK employees.

review_title: Good to start out in but not for all
pros:
Everyone's experience will no doubt be different and no one review will decide how you get on in the company but what I can do is share my experience. Starting off with the positives:

- Good name to have on your CV
- You'll work on big clients , so the experience is good
- Some great people working here, highly skilled and competent. Emphasis on the some.
- Working with Accenture teams is 50/50 depending on the sector they operate in
- If you're entry level its a good place to get exposure to consulting.
-Work life balance is fine when not on a project
cons:
Here's a list of things which evidently made me leave the company:

-Lack of training opportunities , you wont be allowed if you're on a project and you're expected to be on project all the time, its consulting. 
-Projects are normally a mess, all but one were not enjoyable
-Not great pay, will only offer more when you leave
-Hard to get promoted and the people who do are normally the people who have the right connections or in the right circle.
-Heavy focus on chargeability - being on a project above 85% of you time if you're manager and under. If you're not on a project and not chargeable its seen as your fault, even though you have little to no influence on when a project actually lands. Lots of people are given the chargeability excuse when denied promotion. 
-Most people are fine but you get a few people in this org who are quite bullish and will micromanage, order you around and even say things behind your back. 
- International work is highly limited , don't think about it , you'll most likely be stuck in the office you get hired in.

pros: Throughout my 15 year career, I have had the opportunity to work for some great companies, however nothing has been as exciting, challenging and balanced as its been working for Avanade. This is such a progressive and forward-thinking company that truly puts its employees as the centre of it all. They understand what work-life balance is all about and provide employees opportunities to shape their jobs and career paths. They have amazing benefits, opportunities to work based on schedules that make sense for the rest of your life and are constantly evolving their employee experience. Ideas, tech innovation and constant learning has been wonderful and I can't see why I'd want to work anywhere else.
cons: The path to promotion isn't as clear in corporate functions as it is within the consulting practices and at times, you can feel stuck from a growth perspective as it relates to progressing to next level.

review_title: Doesn't live up to the hype
pros: Good EVP. Friendly people. Lots of access to Microsoft training ( if that appeals to you). Financially thriving business due to the Microsoft and Accenture alliances. Pockets of good technical, data and digital talent.
cons:
Trying to reinvent itself and diverge from being purely a Microsoft SI. Has ambitious growth plans, yet distinctly lacking substance at the moment in terms of expertise, market position and reputation to back up the ambition. 

Currently lots of hiring, Avanade is aggressively and successfully "buying" talent in the market. However seem to be hiring for potential over actual performance. 

Some colleagues just don't seem to have the capabilities, confidence, experience or professional standards clients require. This paired with a lack of professional mentorship and coaching leave many staffers lacking the support necessary to grow necessary career competencies. Resulting in the same experienced hires doing the lions share of the work on projects surrounded by some colleagues who are basically window dressing with little to no contribution to make. I've come across too many staff finding ways to disguise the fact they have no work to do, don't understand what they should be doing, or don't have the expertise to do what's necessary. 
There's an acknowledged hero culture driving intense pressure for very capable individuals who quickly find themselves constantly over worked. 

The atmosphere is chaotic and the work life balance can be challenging.

If you want to work in a professional business consulting firm, surrounded by colleagues who have the business consulting pedigree you would expect then I am as sorry I would choose an alternative employer. Don't be misled by the hype and ambition.

On the other hand if you want to work for a firm who has a strong pedigree as a technical system implementer then Avanade is a good choice.

review_title: Really amazing place to work, with great flexibility and work/life balance!
job_title: Senior Security Consultant in Copenhagen, Capital Region
pros:
I've been with the company for 2 years now, and I never felt as appreciated before, as I have been here. Since the first day I started.
I've gotten many "Kudos" and appriciation tokens, giftcards etc throughout the time, and it's always nice having a boss who practically brags about how amazing you are in front of the clients - makes you want to be sure to always deliver your best.
Avanade also have a great work/life balance and flexible working hours, allowing people who might have kids they need to drop off in the kinder-garden or school in the morning, or picking them up at a certain point in the after-noon, do so without any trouble or worry.

One of the absolut biggest things I've experienced here, has been how, if someone is on the bench for a little while, management is more worried about the person not getting bored, and having trainings or other things to do, rather than "KPI's" and "Chargable hours".
it's such a blessing being told "oh no, don't worry about the numbers, that's not your responsibility. You can't work on clients if we don't bring them to you, we're looking for a new client for you, so please bear with us. Hope you're not getting too bored!"

Also, there are plenty of opportunities for moving around, getting promoted etc.

in my 12 years, this is the absolute best company I've worked for
cons:
Comparing to previous companies I've worked at, I can't really think of a "con" per say.
the level is very high, and therefore the expectations and requirements, too, but that's to ensure, Avanade stays amongst the absolut best in the world.

While I was off work my manager switched roles and was replaced by someone who had it out for me from the beginning just because I took medical leave. HR did absolutely nothing to protect me, they let him make up a reason to fire me.

Also, even though the short term leave benefits provider approved my leave, they denied paying me for any of the time I was out of work. I supplied all of the necessary medical paperwork and it was approved for the leave, but not for payment. How is that even possible? I had multiple medical doctors sign off on the paper work. Absolutely horrible medical leave benefits if that isn't already obvious.

pros:
Good client opportunities 
Good resources for training
Passionate about inclusion and diversity
cons:
Low pay compared to other consultancies. Shocking how low the more junior staff are paid when promoted compared to other companies who promote people. Can take 2-3 years on average to get a promotion for an extra 4 grand a year. When you break down the extra hours we spend after 5:30 workingm we are paid pretty poorly.


We are expected to do non client work e.g internal initiatives which can take a good few hours a week which end up being done after work hours due to demanding client work. We do not get paid or rewarded for this. We are told this will help our promotion cases but in truth people have done really good jobs with these initiatives and not been rewarded.

They promote work/life balance but no one really sees it.

job_title: Senior Analyst/Software Developer in Dallas, TX
pros: If there are any pros, its overshadowed by the cons.
cons:
First off, never join this company as a Senior Analyst. They will make up reason to keep you at that level and prevent promotions unless you have major advocate as your "Career Advisor". Managers and Career Advisors are on some sort of power trip. They belittle, threaten, and demean every chance they get. This is the Southwest region btw. 

Client over everything. If the client treats you like absolute garbage and lies about promises, you have to be "flexible" and they will gaslight you saying they never made said promises. They don't care if your sick or your losing money on traveling. They will use you and discard you as they see fit and Avanade/Accenture does not care because client(money) > you.

Don't waste your time at this company. Terrible work-life balance. They talk big about being caring about their employees but that's it-they're just talk. A lot of hypocrisy.

Major turnover the past few months so I'm guessing most of the reviews are not legitimate here. Seriously, if you're looking to travel or get experience in software development, this is not the place. You get sick of living out of suit case and you learn very little as 40+ hrs a week are fast paced and no one bothers to give work geared towards your experience. Or you're forced to work on a project that is not in your career path which in turn hurts your resume. The salary they offer is not worth the emotional distress of this job. This job has convinced me it never was.

review_title: Where smart people come to have fun
job_title: User Experience Designer in Seattle, WA
pros:
I worked in the Seattle office where I worked as a UX designer. Immediately, I noticed a close-knit community that is welcoming and friendly. From what I saw, most people got along with each other very well.

The type of work is really hard to predict as it is a consulting company. Your day-to-day tasks will vary depending on the industry of your client. That's also the reason why it makes the work fun because you don't know who you will be working for next, who you will be working with, and what kind of skills you might learn.

The organizational structure is also very flat. We can ping anyone for a coffee chat and the culture welcomes it greatly.
cons:
There are two main turnoffs for this company. 

1. The company is very homogenous and White male dominant. There is a serious lack of diversity in the office. They do have a lot of women in leadership as it is one of their diversity focus, but in terms of racial diversity, I only saw a handful of Black and Latinx employees. As someone who values diversity, inclusion, equity, and justice in the workplace, I think Avanade needs to focus on hiring and cultivating more talent of varying backgrounds.

2. Sometimes you won't get on a project for a long time. I've seen a few people leave because they were on the bench for extended periods of time. It can be even more exhausting to not get picked up from the bench than being on a rigorous project.

pros:
Slight opportunity to get experience in different industries.
Some employees will create study groups to pass certifications and share
 knowledge.

Some remote work, but really depends on the client.

Extended Benefits is like a guaranteed bonus, but it's limited to what you can spend it on.

New stock opportunities with Accenture, Avanade's parent company.

There really are a lot of great, nice people to work with. Once you get on a project with people you like working with, you need to do everything you can to keep extending on that project, because the unfortunate risk is that another project has a high chance of being the opposite, especially when run by Accenture leadership, but also with more and more Avanade managers.

It's a job. Of course that's good, but it's also a way to springboard your career elsewhere. Get certified, gain industry skill, pad up that resume, and get a better job at a company that does what you like to do and use technologies that you like to work with.
cons:
You are a resource. That's it. They show off that "employees are Avanade's #1 asset", but that's all smoke and mirrors. You are there to make money for the company. That's it. They have no loyalty to you outside of that, if you can even call that loyalty.

By default, they'll give you an underpowered laptop as if all we do is write Word documents. You need to prove an exception to get a more powerful one, as if being a software engineer isn't proof enough.

Benefits shifted to be aligned with Accenture. Health Insurance options got A LOT more expensive.

You have almost no say at all in the projects you go to and the technologies you work with. They will lock you onto a project either without your knowledge or no chance for you to say no, so you can't go to a different one where you could grow your career with skills and technologies you like. You go where they want you to. Your only chance is to be lucky enough to roll off a project and another one has stuff you like to work on. If you're lucky.

They do pay for certification exams, but that's about the only good thing. They push the agenda to get them, but it's ONLY to check the boxes and flaunt some gold status to the world about how many employees are certified. Your chances of getting on a project to use those certifications is almost nil. Again, you get staffed on projects they want to put you on.

No clear guidelines on what qualifies you for promotion to the next level. It's drastically different between regions and even changes within a region with each cycle. Reasons they gave for stack ranking someone one time won't necessarily be applicable to others the next time. That makes it very difficult to know what to work on to get promoted.

There's often very little notice that your project is about to end.

Getting onto many projects requires a round of interviews, which you might as well apply full-time to work at that client instead. It's practically the same process.

There is a clear leftist agenda. You need to be woke enough to work here. Avanade is in lock step with making sure you jump on that bandwagon. They definitely do that through their townhall meetings (such as their lecture about "white privilege" and "police brutality", trying to make us feel guilty about it, which was utterly disgraceful) and compliance training, but also through insinuated pressures via other meetings and company-wide emails. You need to remain silent, otherwise, if you have moral and ethical values in life.

review_title: Best job I have so far!
pros:
I wanna make a post here for future employees to see as a reference to decide if you wanna join. This is a 100% honest post. Everything is a personal opinion and not influenced by anybody else.

As someone who's socially awkward and possibly has ADHD this is the best job I have so far. I joined the company during covid and worked 100% remotely, never meet any colleague in real life. Everything we do is work-related, no unneeded social interaction and this makes me very comfortable. No more "everyone-go-to-a-bar-and-grab-drink" type of event which I HATED in the past during my last few jobs. This is probably a unique situation due to covid but I'm really thankful for that.

As someone who hates working on things long-term, Avanade's project usually spans from 3-9 months depending on your TC. I love, love, love this because I get tired of things so quickly and this allows me to shift between many interesting types of work. Every time you shift to another project you work with new people, learn some new skills, and expand your network and knowledge which is awesome.

I wish I knew this type of company exists when I first graduated out of college. I worked on different types of tech companies before and hated all of them.. Now I figured in-house tech team is not my thing and I'm so happy I joined Avanade.

There's no "you can't do this, you can't do that" type of BS that I encounter in my last few jobs. Everyone is super talented, supportive. You can email anyone requesting help for anything as long as keeping it professional. No more "you can't email this guy because he's the director of x, you need to email this person first and then that" type of bureaucracy.
cons: The pay is a bit low comparing to most tech companies. However, this is not really a concern for me because I believe you get rich by investing not grinding. Plus the difference is not really that big, so don't make this as the single reason you decide not to join.

review_title: Working quality is based on your placed client/project
pros: If you get good and rewarding client/project, you will enjoy your work here. Some client or Avanade's client management have work life balance, allowance, interesting technology used in project and good leadership. However still you can't stay in a client more than 2 years. Usually a project will end within months and after that you'll get transfer to another client and project.
cons: Get assign to which client is never a choice. It assigned to you by the management and you'll have to follow, no choice. If you get bad client/project, you're life will be like hell. Some project force you to work like a slave, no work life balance, no allowance. 24/7 including holidays work is normal in these projects. Bosses want to meet client's impossible expectation and timeline and employees are the victim. You'll never get out from bad project because they cannot find replacement for you because nobody want to work is bad project. So , you'll stuck there forever. Resign is the only option left. All Avanade Malaysia projects are under Accenture. Avanade management have little to no control over the project because of Accenture's dominant and that's what making the employee suffer.

review_title: "Woe, woe, woe to the inhabitants of the Avanade..."
pros:
Client Exposure - Interesting projects to work on.
Work Ethic - Lots of good people trying to do a great job
Benefits - Accenture is your benefactor, at times.
Career - for people starting out ...this is a good place to get a couple years experience.
cons: Avanade is a company created by two huge companies and are indentured to each. It is a company incapable of coherent independent thought. It is merely a vehicle to serve a profit goal. That's ok, but it has created a level of dysfunction that is hard to measure on a scale, if you could, it would be off that scale. I worked in the IT group and managed multiple projects a year, the work was usually driven by Accenture which is a toss up, especially when they expect you to be on location 4 days a week for months. The marketing organization couldn't manage a bake sale much less a message that drove anybody to understand who Avanade actually is ...most clients have never heard of them. That makes things hard on projects. After almost 20 years in the market, that's quite an achievement in being invisible. If you are a decade or two into your career, stay away, this is not a good place to add to your resume. That was my mistake. And don't be fooled by the short-on-content positive ratings, interns probably do them by the dozen.

review_title: Sub-par pay, benefits in full nosedive.
pros: Avanade use to be a great place to work, however it seems that the company has shifted focus from people first to money, and Accenture first.
cons: The pay was already sub-par, however, the benefits made up for that. Recently Avanade decided to eliminate paid sick time and lump it in with PTO, their justification is that they increased PTO accrual… by one hour per pay period. So, now you have to choose between taking a sick day or getting to take a vacation. And, to top it off, they decided to “harmonize” with Accenture regarding benefits, such as health insurance which resulted in the out of pocket cost almost doubling! And you can bet that there will not be any comparable raise to compensate. Furthermore, when approaching leadership regarding these changes their response: "Well who else is hiring", or "try to go find another job", it's absolutely atrocious. “It’s not an Accenture takeover” but it absolutely seems like it. It’s always going to be Accenture first. Avanade, you’ve lost your identity.

pros:
There is a pool of high performing talent and inspirational individuals.
You get an opportunity to take ownership of what you do and some of that is genuinely exciting stuff! (but see cons).
Grateful that they retained jobs during a trying time.
cons:
Work life balance is poorer than similar consultancies but is badged as a selling point.
The organisational structure is unclear, barring a hierarchy based on career level and you are pulled in multiple directions by different people ‘laying claim’ to you and your time. These people are often not motivated by the success of the wider organisation but their own career advancement, the two rarely align within the organisation. This con is in part tied to my pro about owning your future, but with it failing in practice more recently.
Our ability to or willingness to invest and execute on what we talk about is diminished. Whether that’s innovative work with clients or internal development and initiatives. We talk a lot and focus less on doing it the last fiscal year.
Proper process is thrown out the window if it gets in the way of the people trying to win work. This ultimately impacts the people who have to deliver it.
Recruitment process is long, painful and complacent. Many of us had 4 interviews including the screening process, most of it was very repetitive with gaps of sometimes a month or two between steps with no reason given. Tech is competitive!
